Zoe, I follow you for about 8-10 years now, I think pretty much since you started your channel, and in all that time I think I only left a comment about 2 or 3 times tops - Iâ€™m not a very interactive person myself. But today thereâ€™s was NO WAY I could ever leave this video without telling you how important that video was, it was an amazing idea to do it, and THANK YOU so much for doing this. I am a nurse and one of my favorite parts in university was when I was working with educating young women and teenagers about HPV and cervical cancer, as well as breast cancer. I did an educational program for almost two years, going to schools and talking to girls and boys starting at 14 about sexual education, how to prevent cancer and other STDs, and it is amazing how many questions and doubts one can have, and I think the sooner you start learning about how your body works, how you can prevent diseases, how all those things are completely NORMAL, the better. You can save so many lives (yes! Saving lives! Cervical cancer kills a lot of women every year) by just educating people, and I love it that you are more than aware of how much of a influence you have, and you use it for such a good cause. Thank you, Zoe! You are an amazing human being!
Oh and I do hope your results came back all normal and you are completely healthy! Congratulations for your amazing work!

Thank you so much for sharing this with us Zoe. In the US things are a little different as far as pap smears go. I was 16 when I had my first test after finding a cyst on one of my ovaries. (In the US, you go as soon as you're sexually active, or if you're getting put on birth control) It was the worst experience I've ever had. They MALE doctors didn't explain ANYTHING and I was so scared that I actually passed out after it was over and he left the room. (yeah I'm still embarrassed to say that) I wish this video was around 8 years ago. I am now 24, and have found a female doctor that I am completely 100% comfortable around and there is no more stress or anxiety when I go to my appointments. My biggest tip is to find a doctor that you are comfortable around. It will make the process so much easier. Thanks again Zoe.

Such a good video! It shouldn't be scary for people to have this done, but it can be daunting. I had my second test yesterday on a very hot day and was worried about being sweaty and gross. My nurse was lovely and we joked about it and she turned on her desk fan for me, which did blow the paper I was using to cover up across the room! It was hilarious and we both laughed and I wasn't bothered about being exposed at all, because I already was to an extent! I think it made her day and I certainly made a good impression! She spoke to me throughout the procedure, explaining different things and we had a nice chat! I was barely in there for ten minutes and had very little discomfort. I get the results in a couple of weeks, which is fairly quick for my doctor's surgery. But I always do make a big effort to be extra kind to the nurse as they do so many of these tests it must get a bit repetitive, but also could be nerve-wracking for them, and they are still human! So, don't be scared for the test and please go get checked out :)
